avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche danger is moderate above 2400 metres and low below. Storms from the northwest have been depositing fresh wind slab snow on an unfavourably built-up old snow surface for several days. From around 2400 m, avalanches can be triggered by individuals in some places and occasionally become medium-sized. There is a risk of burial in particular near terrain traps, i.e. in areas adjacent to the ridgeline, crest or summit. The drift snow packs are usually easily recognisable.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Prone to triggering fresh wind slab.

snowpackStructure.comment: The snow cover, snowpack is highly variable. On the surface, in leeward areas, there is a succession of fresh drift snow layers on the melt-freeze crust of the old snow surface. Fractures are most possible here, the drift snow layers are poorly connected to each other and to the melt-freeze crust in some places. Underneath, there is usually edgy snow with no binding. Due to the overall heavily built-up transformed snow cover, the potential for fracture propagation in the old snowpack is generally low. The snow depth is well below average at all altitudes.

tendency.highlights: No significant change in the avalanche danger on Saturday.

weatherForecast.comment: The sun may still be out at the start of the day on Friday, but the weather will then increasingly deteriorate from the north. A little new fallen snow may fall during the daytime changes, but no more than 5 cm is expected. Short gaps of cloud may form from time to time. The wind will blow briskly from the west on the mountains at around 70 km/h at times. Temperatures will drop again, reaching around -8 degrees at 2000 metres and -13 degrees at 3000 metres.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche danger is low. Up to 20 cm of new fallen snow has been brought down by north-westerly winds over the last few days on ground that was previously mostly bare. Touring options remain severely limited and snow relevant for burial can only accumulate in well-recognised terrain traps. However, the risk of avalanches is outweighed by the risk of injury from underlying rocks.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Watch out locally for small snowdrift accumulations.

snowpackStructure.comment: There is a succession of thin layers of drifting snow on the meadows. The snow cover is well below average and very variable.

tendency.highlights: The avalanche danger remains low on Saturday despite some new fallen snow.

weatherForecast.comment: In the second half of the night, increasingly compact cloud fields will move in from the north. The wind picks up on the peaks during the night and reaches speeds of around 60 km/h in the morning hours. On Friday, the weather will increasingly deteriorate from the north and bring more snow showers. The amounts are still uncertain, but more than 10 cm will likely not fall anywhere. Short gaps of cloud may form from time to time. The wind on the mountains will be brisk at times from the west with gusts of around 60 km/h. Temperatures will drop again, reaching around -8 degrees at 2000 metres.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche risk is low, but injuries from stones and falling remain the main dangers. Some wind slab has accumulated on a small scale. This is easily recognisable and can only be disturbed by individuals in isolated cases. In gullies and bowls adjacent to the ridgeline, crests or summits in shady slopes, there are isolated trigger points in persistent weak layers that are difficult to disturb.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Rare release points and risk of injury from stones.

snowpackStructure.comment: There is a below-average amount of snow and the snow cover, snowpack is highly variable in the interior. In shady slopes at high altitudes, weak layers of faceted crystals are occasionally preserved in the snow cover, mostly in the vicinity of crusts. The fracture propagation potential is generally low due to the overall highly structured snow cover, snowpack.

tendency.highlights: The avalanche danger remains low on Saturday.

weatherForecast.comment: The sun may still be out at the start of the day on Friday, but visibility will increasingly deteriorate from the north. A few centimetres of snow may fall with light snow showers during the daytime changes. Short gaps of cloud may form from time to time. The wind will blow briskly from the west on the mountains at around 70 km/h at times. Temperatures will drop again, reaching around -8 degrees at 2000 metres.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche danger is low. With new fallen snow and stormy winds from the northwest, fresh prone-to-triggering snow packs have been forming for a few days, which can be triggered by individuals in a few places from around 2200 metres. Most avalanches remain small, but enough snow could accumulate in isolated terrain traps to bury people. Be careful behind exposed ridges and ridgelines, in gullies and bowls. In shady slopes, there are still very occasional trigger points in persistent weak layers that are difficult to disturb. The drift snow packs are usually easily recognisable, stones under the thin snow cover, snowpack often not.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh wind slab prone to triggering.

snowpackStructure.comment: The snow cover, snowpack is highly variable. On the surface, in leeward areas, there is a succession of fresh drift snow layers on the melt-freeze crust of the old snow surface. Fractures are most possible here, the drift snow layers are poorly connected to each other and to the melt-freeze crust in some places. Underneath, there is usually edgy snow with no binding. Due to the overall heavily built-up transformed snow cover, the potential for fracture propagation in the old snowpack is generally low. The snow depth is well below average at all altitudes.

tendency.highlights: The avalanche danger increases slightly on Saturday with new fallen snow and wind.

weatherForecast.comment: During the night, the wind will pick up in the northern Alps (peaks around 60 km/h) and compact cloud fields will gather. On Friday, the sun may still appear in some places in the south at the start of the day. From midday onwards, light snow showers will occur in the northern Alps and later on as far as the central Alps. The amounts are still uncertain, but it is likely that no more than 10 cm will fall anywhere. Short gaps of cloud may form from time to time. The wind will blow briskly from the west on the mountains with gusts of around 70 km/h, and even stronger on the peaks of the northern mountain groups. Temperatures will drop again, reaching around -8 degrees at 2000 metres, -13 degrees at 3000 metres in the south and -17 degrees in the north.

ALBINA.generalHeadline: Fresh snow packs prone to triggering
